translated: Indeed, this Tejobindu Upanishad, divided into the Krishna Yajur Veda, shines forth as the enlightener of the meaning of the liberation of the body characterized by the state of the undivided bliss of consciousness, established by the denial of the consciousness that is divided into parts other than itself. Its introduction and so on are the same as in the Katha Valli and other (Upanishads). The commentary on this Tejobindu Upanishad, which illuminates the experience of Brahman alone, is begun in a few words.

translated: The story of the questions of Shiva, Skanda, and Ribhu, and the replies, which will be mentioned later, is for the praise of knowledge. Here, at the beginning, in the first chapter, without the arrangement of questions and answers, the Shruti itself teaches the truth of Brahman without distinctions, which is accomplished by the means of the fifteen-limbed yoga, to those who are qualified as stated, with the words Tejobindu. For those sages who desire to contemplate on the nature of their own Self, for those sages who have a mind for the meditation on Brahman without distinctions, for those wise ones also, I will speak of that supreme meditation which has as its object the form of the Tejobindu, which is the mere Self without any counter-correlate, and which is accomplished by the denial of the darkness of ignorance and its effects other than one's own Self. What is the object of meditation? To this he says Vishva etc. He who has as his body the entire universe, which is trusted by one's own ignorant self as existing separately, is this Vishvatma, the Virata. In the lotus of his heart, in the midst of the thousand petals, is the Tejobindu, which is the mere Self without any counter-correlate, and which is accomplished by the denial of the darkness of ignorance and its effects other than one's own Self.
The means of realizing Brahman without distinction

translated: They who have taken refuge in the variegated Brahman, who are followers of their own knowledge, know that the waking state is in the eye. In the face established by the Vedic text The universe is in the right eye, the waking state, etc. have three forms each, as the locus of the unity of the individual, the universal, and both, in the distinctions of the universe, the universe, etc., the Viraj, the Viraj, etc., the Yoni, the Yoni, etc. By the word ca (and), the forms of each of those four are also included. They find, they know, by their own non-difference. Thus, he who has three abodes is called the three-abode Gander. The Gander is the Supreme Lord, who destroys his own self by his own knowledge. He, being free from sloth, being free from dependence on others, having become independent, that which is said to be identified with Him, being the locus of all negations, is beyond the conception of the waking state, etc. Being inexpressible to one who is not qualified, it is the secret Brahman, the supernal abode that depends on the abode to be supernally abided in.

translated: The Brahman, which is established by the denial of the category of ignorance other than itself and the host of its effects, is the mere self without an opposite. The state of being that mere Brahman is the characteristic of disembodied liberation. That is being elaborated here with having become Brahman and so on. He has become Brahman because he abides as mere Brahman. His soul is tranquil because he has the idea of the three bodies being tranquil. He is full of Brahman's bliss because he is of the nature of bliss, meaning he is mere Brahman's bliss without an opposite. He is of pure form because he is of the nature of perfect knowledge. He is the great silent one because he abides silently as the mere self. The bodies are the three bodies characterized by ignorance and the host of its effects belonging to the self. The ideas of I and mine are the roots. The bodies are devoid of them. They are the disembodied ones. They themselves are the Vaidehas. He has them, so he is the Vaidehi. If he were designated in that form, he would be bound. Therefore, he says liberated. Where the liberated one, who has been denied as being different from himself, has gone, that is this Vaidehi, who is liberated indeed.

translated: He said: What is that? Here, all words are the limit of all words because of being soundless. The limit of all thought is the western direction because of swallowing the activity of thought etc. It is the self of all causes and effects by the view of one's own ignorance etc. It is the essence of all sound because of being the meaning of the Vedanta scriptures born from sound. It is mere consciousness devoid of all that is offered by one's own ignorance. It is said to be the object of one's own experience, meditation etc. to have particularity. Therefore, it is said to be all etc. The meaning of the sentence that thou art is the Self. Therefore, it is said to be the great sentence etc. It is devoid of the perishable and the imperishable because of being the supreme syllable devoid of the proliferation of the perishable and the imperishable. Of the supreme Self, by the meaning of the various sentences scattered about, it is devoid of the words existence, consciousness, bliss and their denotations. Therefore, it is to be indicated. It goes to a state of being directly unknowable by the Vedic sentences of the Karma Kanda. Therefore, it is the agamyaga.

translated: What was asked by Nidaghna, Please tell me the true nature of the self and the not-self, in that, this self is established by denying what is other than itself, the state of ignorance and its effects. Thus, the true nature of the self has been stated. Now, the true nature of the not-self is being stated as not-self. There is not even the news that the not-self exists or does not exist. Even in the absence of ignorance in the form of ignorance, ignorance may be in the form of the mind, which is its effect, or in the form of waking. Therefore, it is said that the not-self does not exist. The world, which is the effect of the mind, also does not exist. Since it is so, therefore, O Nidaghna, be certain that the not-self does not exist in any form, either as an effect or a cause. Be convinced that there is no ignorance here, nor illusion. For those who investigate the truth of things, ignorance itself does not exist as long as ignorance exists.

translated: The meaning that is stated by this and other statements, namely that one's own nature alone is established by negating everything other than oneself, considering that meaning to be difficult to understand, the scripture repeatedly brings up the topic, as much as possible, of the knowledge of Brahman alone, established by negating what is other than itself, in order to manifest its own ignorance. Having first taught the nature of undivided, pure consciousness through an intermediate statement beginning with the point of light along with the knowledge and yoga of fifteen limbs, and having translated: From I will sleep in my own nature up to he is called a living liberated one, he reveals the fruit of living liberation that occurs in between the knowledge of Brahman without distinctions. Beginning with Having become Brahman, with a tranquil self, up to Rejoice in your own self, Vaidehi, attain liberation, he reveals the primary fruit of the knowledge of Brahman alone, which is the liberation of the embodied one characterized by abiding in that alone. Then, taking up another narrative, beginning with Brahman is the end of all speech and so on, he teaches the true nature of one's own self. Beginning with Or the occurrence of 'not-self' and so on, he teaches the true nature of the not-self. Having loosened the connection between the two by the statement self and not-self, the possibility of oneness and difference between the two, by dependent Vedic statements and reasonings such as In the absence of one, the second is not, in some places, he establishes the nature of one's own self alone as a relation without an opposite, by the difference in words and meaning between the self and the not-self that are different from one's own self, and the non-existence of this world and so on of a general that is different from one's own self.

translated: Thus, a seeker of liberation who has obtained knowledge from the mouth of a guru should abandon the study of all Upaniá¹£ads. Having renounced everything, what is the use of practicing this? Therefore he says Once. The meaning is that by merely hearing and reciting once, the wise one remains only in Brahman, which is established by the denial of all and is without a counter-correlate. The word Upaniá¹£ad means the completion of the Tejobindu Upaniá¹£ad.
